text: Appian Road is empty at this time of a day. There is only long shadow of PETER THE APOSTLE, who looks ahead at the hilly surrounding area. Beneath his hood you can see his grave expression and tired face. The sun begins to appear from over the hillsides. Peter shields his eyes with his hand, trying to see the white pigeon, which flapped its wings loudly. Peter sinks to his knees, resting his hands and head on h staff. Around his outline appears a pulsing, golden light Than the single beam of light splits like a prism into tw streaks - one of them is pale pink - another clear luminous. The staff slides from under him and he falls face down i the Sand, his head still covered by his hood. Peter stretches his hands forward as if reaching for someoneвЂ™ feet. Silence falls. The golden light fades. Peter raises his h slightly.
Quo Vadis, Domine?
The screen lights up with "Quo Vadis". (ENTER OPENING CREDITS)

The interior of PETRONIUSвЂ™S home. Petronius stands in his atrium close to a pool filled wit fresh water. There is a statue of Petronius behind him. B he and his statue stand motionless. Petronius observes th golden haired EUNICE, who is straightening the folds in h tunic. MARK VINICIUS enters the atrium with the springy step of soldier.
Greetings Petronius! May the Gods bring you prosperity!

By Jupiter! My nephew Marcus Vinicius! A true god of war. Dear me, let me embrace you! Petronius makes a sudden movement towards Marcus Vinicius unknowingly almost knocking Eunice over. Petronius hugs Vinicius.
Welcome back to Rome! You return from the war in Armenia? Vinicius takes a step back and turns sideways to Petroniu
Yes and a sorry business it is, a totally unnecessary war! He retreats further into the chamber. Petronius follows h and puts a hand on his shoulder. Vinicius turns his head.
A true soldier turns away from war only when love has him enslaved. Do I guess correctly? Vinicius remains silent.
Has CupidвЂ™s arrow pierced your heart? Vinicius face glows with radiance.
What a perceptive judge of people you are, Petronius! No wonder youвЂ™re CeaserвЂ™s chief counselor.
To advise Nero, itвЂ™s sufficient to know the ways of monkeys. What am I saying! Even monkeys are not so stupid as to believe everything theyвЂ™re told.
Is it that bad at the Palatine? War lets you forget about those things.

War even allows one to believe that thereвЂ™s a method to all this madness. But Rome will soon cure you of any such illusions. Unless, youвЂ™ve been enchanted by somemermaid. Speak up, boy! Vinicius grabs his arm and begins to speak rapidly.

Returning from the battle, I stopped at the house of Aulus Plautius. He made me most welcome, and that was where I saw her. One day, at dawn, I caught sight of her at the fountain. The morning rays (cD)
seemed to pass right through her body. ViniciusвЂ™ face beams. Petronius laughs.
As transparent as a young sardine! So you truly have fallen in love with a mermaid!
FLASHBACK. Slow motion. LIGIA is seen from behind standin next to a fountain and dipping her hand in the cool water She turns to the camera and smiles with girlish innocence
Vinicius stands admiring Ligia. He is at first struck dum by her beauty.
Are you Venus?[Pause] Because only a goddess could look like that. Ligia stares at Vinicius, but makes no reply. A girlish smile full of curiosity spreads across her face.
Allow me Vinicius stutters like a nervous schoolboy.
.to... Ligia bends down and with her finger draws the "Pisces" symbol in the sand. Vinicius suddenly crouches beside her and when he tries to take her by the hand, but LigiaвЂ™s gives him the slip.
They call her Lygia, but her name is Callina. She makes... this hunger burn inside me. She must be mine.
Petronius watches with amusement as Vinicius nervously pa up and down the terrarium alongside the pool.
The maiden or the fish?
Both. In the meantime, several beautiful slave girls enter - tw Ethiopians, three slender Greeks and Eunice.
Better fish than these you see here are not to be found in all of Rome. Eunice! An intimidated Eunice walks up to them.
What do you think of Eunice? She smells of violets. Even I do not know how sweet her kisses taste. Take her. Eunice throws herself at PetroniusвЂ™ feet, pleading.

Please, Master, donвЂ™t send me away. Petronius is visibly upset by her disobedience. Vinicius turns down the offer by shaking his head and turning his back to them as an Ethiopian slave presents a bowl of oils for Petronius to rinse his hands.
I want only Lygia. She is worth a hundred of these. She is the daughter of kings. Petronius wipes his brow, wraps his arm around ViniciusвЂ shoulder and leads him towards the exit.
You mentioned hunger? LetвЂ™s go for breakfast. That will refresh the body, and then weвЂ™1ll do something for the soul. What do you think of (cD)

the Plautiuses? What do you say we pay them a visit? After they exit, the slaves pick up all the baskets and bowls and leave. Eunice looks around and when she sees no one is looking s runs up to the statue of Petronius, stands on her toes an lightly kisses him on the lips.

House of Aulus Plautius. Interior decorations in the atri leading to the garden. Petronius and Vinicius stand opposite their hosts, POMPON and AULUS PLAUTIUS. Beyond, in the courtyard, can be seen wonderful fountain. The pearls of water shine and reflect the sun with a rainbow. Petronius bows his head towards the hosts.
I thank you for the hospitality you gave my sisterвЂ™s son.
AS you well know, Petronius,I spent half my life on the battlefield. Seeing Marcus reminded me of my younger years. Today, as we grow older, our whole world lies within these walls.

In my soul I think how different your world is from that over which our Nero reigns. Suddenly he turns his head at the sound of joyful laughte from a girl and child. Running up from the atrium is Lygia and little AULUS. The boy stumbles and falls at the feet of Petronius. Petronius and Lygia both lean down to pick up the child. Their eyes meet and lock momentarily. The little boy gets up on his own and runs out of the roo Lygia runs after him. Pomponia replies to Petronius with a wise, gentle smile.
ItвЂ™s not Nero, but God who rules the world. Petronius turns towards Vinicius. Vinicius is standing as still as a statue, staring at the place where Lygia left room.
There are many gods, everyone has his own. Pomponia responds with conviction.
There is only one God - just and omnipotent

Lightning. The contours of the street slowly emerge. Petronius and Vinicius are being carried in a litter. Beneath them the heads of noble pedestrians flash by. The litter, held up by runners, turns sharply through the crowd and its passengers almost fall out.

And so you are writing poems? ThatвЂ™s quite the fashion these days. But you must be careful - Redbeard canвЂ™t abide competition. So youвЂ™d better be writing bad poems or none at all. Petronius smiles sadly. ViniciusвЂ™s expression does not change, then he suddenly explodes.
I donвЂ™t care about Caesar, nor do I care about poetry! Petronius shakes his head impatiently.
I do believe you really are in love.  Vinicius is uncomfortable in the litter. He bangs on the side and the runners come to a halt. Vinicius jumps out i the street among the crowd.
And you, were you never in love? He yells at Petronius. Petronius gives him a manuscript a he leaves.
WhatвЂ™s this?

Poems. The author: Redbeard. Required reading. "Nero Augustus Ceasar" is written on the parchment. Vinicius shakes his head and moves away disappearing into the crowd. Petronius taps with his cane for the runners t continue.
To the Palatine Hill, CeasarвЂ™s palace! The litter hastily moves away.
The house of Aulus Plautius. The CENTURION HASTO enters w several PRAETORIAN GUARDS. The host stands in front of th group of soldiers. The centurion bows his head slightly.
Commander! I bring you greetings from Caesar! Plautius frowns.
Speak up Hasto! What is the charge? The centurion takes a step forward.
No charges against you, sir, but an order from Caesar: the Divine Nero is grateful to you for giving shelter to the daughter of the barbarian king. But as a hostage, (cD)

the girl belongs to Caesar. Therefore our divine emperor commands you to hand her over. Plautius turns around and looks at his wife, to whom Lygi is clinging. Next to the women stands the powerfully buil URSUS.
Tears stream down the cheeks of Lygia and Pomponia. Plaut says with a voice that trembles.
Lygia! Both Pomponia and I love you like a daughter, but you are CaesarвЂ™s responsibility ... Aulus walks past the women and disappears into the house. Ursus kneels before Pomponia.
Domina! Allow me to go with my lady to the house of Caesar. She wipes away her tears.
You are not mine, but LygiaвЂ™s servant, Ursus! Guard her closely! Little Aulus runs into the room and clings to LygiaвЂ™s l crying as Pomponia makes the sign of the cross on her forehead.
May the Lord watch over you, daughter. Trust the God and believe that his mercy endures for ever.

Plautius steps out of his litter and heads into the home Petronius. On a shaded patio, Vinicius trains with his sword. He sto training at the sight of Plautius. Aulus Plautius and Vinicius stand opposite each other. Th commanderвЂ™s face is drawn in anger.  10.
I curse the moment you and Petronius crossed the threshold of our house!
Plautius! What are you saying? Why, I am the most faithful of all your friends!
You are a thief! You have stolen my daughter! Vinicius rushes across to Plautius.
Speak up, tell me what has happened! Where is Lygia? Plautius halts Vinicius with a look, before he can get to worked up.
Your uncle, Petronius persuaded Caesar to take Lygia to the Palatine, to his palace.

The grounds around CaesarвЂ™s palace - Palatine. Twilight growing buzz of laughter and cheers can be heard. The outlines of columns and rows of statues of gods can be se Along them move crowds of people heading towards CaesarвЂ feast. It gets darker; all that can be seen are the outlines of human figures moving in different directions. Somewhere f away music is playing. The light comes from lamps and lanterns, along with torches burning in the gardens. Two female figures are seen passing down a walkway border by perfectly trimmed hedges. They are illuminated by lamp burning on the ground behind them. The camera follows beh them, eventually catching up. One of the women is Lygia. She walks nervously, looking around anxiously. She is dressed in a beautiful gold tuni and a unique hair style. She seems a changed person as sh holds on tightly to the arm of the other woman, ACTE. Her companion is older but also beautiful and speaks with a warm, soothing voice.  11.
You would incur the wrath of Caesar by not attending his banquet. He wants to see you! Fear not, Lygia. IвЂ™1l be right there with you.
You have been at NeroвЂ™s side... As a wife. But IвЂ™m so terribly afraid of him.

That is why I promised Pomponia not to let you out of my sight. Calm yourself Lygia, Caesar will soon forget about you, and his Poppea will never allow him to come close to you! Lygia smileвЂ™s awkwardly as they disappear into the crow guests walking up the stairs.

Two male figures move along a walkway surrounded by illuminated sculptures. They enter into the circle of lig allowing them to be recognized. It is Petronius and Marcu Vinicius. MarcusвЂ™s face is clouded with emotion. Petronius repeat glances at his companion and says with sarcasm.
Cease this silence and grim expression, or they will think that you are hiding a dagger somewhere in the folds of your robes!
This is not what I wanted, Petronius! Petronius places his finger over his lips and laughs.
You know too little of the ways of this world, Marcus. The war has made a savage of you. This is Rome. The centre of the world. Here we handle matters discretely.  12.
Lygia should not have been abducted from the house of the Plautiuses. Petronius responds strongly.
Only the emperor could have taken her away, to then give her to you. You will be able to spend this night in her arms. Vinicius is stopped in his tracks, surprised.

head_text.subj: SCENE 16 NIGHT_INT_ NERO PALACE_ LARGE BANQUETTE HALL

text: Large hall. Palatine - CaesarвЂ™s Palace. A lot of guests tables in a brightly lit room. Candles flicker on the tab and walls but the guests at the tables sit gloomily in silence. Acte comes in with Lygia.

head_text.subj: SCENE 17 NIGHT_INT_ NERO PALACE_ LARGE BANQUETTE HALL

text: The buzz and hum of the banquet. Servants bring in great plates of food. Acte and Lygia are seated behind the long table. Acte nods towards the brightly lit end of the room and it decorated table. Lygia looks towards the throne with disdain. At that moment the room erupts in great applause full of screaming and cheering.

Hail Caesar! Hail Caesar!Hail Caesar ! CEASAR NERO, surrounded by dignitaries, enters the room. Caesar is placed at the table next to his closest court, Among which are two arch-enemies fighting for influence i CaesarвЂ™s court - Petronius and TIGELLINUS - the command chief of the Praetorians. At that moment thousands of yellow rose petals fall from ceiling onto the tables and guests. Lygia stares at Nero. Lygia whispers with fascination.  13.
Redbeard...!

head_text.subj: SCENE 18 NIGHT_INT_ NERO PALACE_ LARGE BANQUETTE HALL

text: NeroвЂ™s table. Caesar looks around the room. After a mom he focuses and squints in one particular direction.
Is this the beauty that Vinicius loves so much? Tigellinus leans over to Caesar and whispers in his ear.
A beauty she is indeed Sire, too beautiful for Vinicius. PetroniusвЂ™s face contorts with anger.

Sire, you are more generous to Vinicius than if you were his own father. Even Tigellinus has noticed she is too narrow in the hips, but as usual he is trying to score. You have missed the boat, Tigellinus! Nero grabs his emerald monocle, puts it up to his eye and stares at Lygia. Both of them await NeroвЂ™s verdict. Ner busts out laughing.
Yes, missed. Too narrow in the hips. Petronius releases a sigh of relief as Tigellinus sends h a deadly stare.

head_text.subj: SCENE 19 NIGHT_INT_ NERO PALACE_ LARGE BANQUETTE HALL

text: Poppea! Poppea! Electrifying cheers run through the room. AUGUSTA POPPEA, the wife of Caesar approaches, majestical gliding across the hall dressed in robes the color of amethyst and wearing gorgeous jewelry and an amazing hairstyle resembling a giant sailing ship.  14. Nero, still staring at Lygia, pays no attention to his wi as he turns the emerald monocle around in front of his ey like a prism. Poppea walks up to Nero and snatches the monocle out of h hand. She stares into his face him and jealously hisses a him.

You donвЂ™t need this, my divine Nero. The greatest beauty is right beside you. Surprised, Nero turns to her with a grimace. He reaches o and tears a ruby from her neck and looks at her through i twirling the stone in front of his eye. POV Nero. This stone is cut with several facets; through we can see five heads of Poppea.

This is a woman with five heads. IвЂ™1l get rid of at least four of them. Her hairdressers cost me too much. Poppea canвЂ™t hide the anger on her face but duly takes place next to her husband as thousands of red rose pedals fall from the ceiling. She mutters under her breath.
You better watch for your own head, Nero.

head_text.subj: SCENE 20 NIGHT_INT_ NERO PALACE_ LARGE BANQUETTE HALL

text: Acte and Lygia at the table. Lygia watches Poppea with delight.
How beautiful she is!
You are a hundred times more beautiful. Lygia hears the voice of Vinicius, who is standing behind her.  15.

Hail, Callina-Lygia! Vinicius takes a place next to the girl, moving Acte to t side. He is wearing a scarlet tunic, his bare arms decora in golden epaulettes. Vinicius reluctantly looks at Acte. He grabs Lygia by her hand and leans over, whispering in her ear. Lygia tries t pull away gently.

I knew IвЂ™d find you here. But little did I know it would make me so happy! Acte begins to intervene as Vinicius pulls Lygia towards him, but upon hearing Nero is going to sing, she interrup wanting everyone to listen to him sing.
Hold your breaths! Caesar is about to sing.

head_text.subj: SCENE 21 NIGHT_INT_ NERO PALACE_ LARGE BANQUETTE HALL

text: Nero recites a poem, posing grotesquely like an actor, wh holding his zither in his hands.

Sweet Venus, founder of Rome and pride of the Gods, You who guard travelers on the high seas, and make the land fruitfull for all living things, the Goddess of sunlight who stills the storm for you clouds clear away... The young FREEDMAN PITAGORAS kneels at the feet of Caesar He removes the laurel wreath from his head and puts it at the feet of Caesar with an expression of adulation on his face.

Oh heavenly voice! Our divine Caesar! Redbeard, the greatest poet in the world! Nero looks quizzically at Petronius and then at Tigellinu then again at Petronius. A boundless self-admiration appe on his face.  16. Petronius remains in an indifferent silence, as if the spectacle did not make the slightest impression on him. Not finding delight in the eyes of Petronius, Nero change his expression to that of a little boy begging for the praise of his father. Petronius drags out the situation b in the end speaks while retaining his stone face.

Cursed be the fate that has us live with such a poet. Were his verses any worst, perhaps I could find it in my heart to praise them. But I remain silent. Embarrassed. Destroyed by their beauty. NeroвЂ™s face lights up with delight and boundless vanity Nero grabs a chalice to take a drink of wine. Pitagoras throws himself to pour more wine for Nero as Tigellinus fumes in jealousy.
Thy verses, Caesar, were born like you among the gods. Their father is Zeus Apollo and their mother.... Nero turns red in anger.
Silence Fool! My mother was Agrippina, a cursed woman... A gloomy expression appears on NeroвЂ™s face.

I had no choice; I had to sentence her to death, because she sent an assassin to murder me. If I hadnвЂ™t acted quicker than her, you would not have heard me singing today. Tigellinus, wanting to calm CaesarвЂ™s anger, yells out w excitement in his face as he raises a glass of wine.

On behalf of the city and the world I thank you Caesar for destroying your mother and freeing us from her evil power.  17. With contempt Petronius stares at Tigellinus and reaches NeroвЂ™s emerald monocle, putting it up to his eye. Throu he sees the weird party and its already drunk guests, hugging, kissing, raising glasses and eating. In the background, shadowy slaves move around carrying massive trays of food and pitchers of wine. The image is drowned by another precipitation of multicolored rose petals. Petronius removes the sapphire from his eye and hands it to Nero, jolting him from his m distant stare.
Close your ears, Nero, lest the words of fools hurt them. Your world is like an emerald. Rare and fragile.

head_text.subj: SCENE 22 NIGHT_INT_ NERO PALACE_ LARGE BANQUETTE HALL

text: An already drunk Vinicius wraps his arms around Lygia. Sh tries to get out of his grasp.
Lygia, Lygia...! Kiss me! Caesar has promised you to me...!

head_text.subj: SCENE 23 NIGHT_INT_ NERO PALACE_ LARGE BANQUETTE HALL

text: Loud noises as Gladiators enter the arena between the tables. With bare bodies rubbed in oil, they begin to battle. Two guests shake hands.

I wager that Croto will wring his neck! The fight continues. One of the gladiators wins an advantage, choking his opponent and throwing him to the ground. The winner puts a foot on the back of his foe and crosses his arms over his chest in a sign of victory. The hall erupts in the cheers of the men and women looking on.
Croto! Croto! Croto!  18.

head_text.subj: SCENE 24 NIGHT_INT_ NERO PALACE_ LARGE BANQUETTE HALL

text: Vinicius tries to kiss Lygia, in the struggle she knocks over a cup of wine. HeвЂ™s drunk, with no control over himself. He mumbles, meanwhile Acte tries to stop him.

[Drunk] Love me, Lygia! It was I that beat the Parthians and bore the glory of Rome to the world. And now Rome gives me my due reward worthy of a hero. You!...(his speech slurs off into drunken mumbling) Lygia tries to push him away with her last ounce of strength. Acte tries to restrain him. At this moment a gigantic form appears above Vinicius. A giant - Ursus appears from behind Vinicius and picks Ly up like a doll. They disappear among the guests and servants, meanwhile Vinicius is too drunk to realize what happening.
House of Petronius. Atrium. Petronius is walking alongsid the pool, scolding Vinicius, who is hiding his face in hi hands.

It is as I feared. This war has made a savage of you. You have become one of us. A bastard of the court. Redbeard can be proud of you. I have forfeited the friendship of the Plautiuses just to decorate your empty head with a wreath of withered leaves. Vinicius drops his head in shame. Petronius is furious. Eunice silently slips into the room and turns towards Petronius.
Master, I found the man that youвЂ™re looking for and who is looking for you. From behind Eunice appears a clumsy figure of an old man a torn coat, who bows and mutters. CHILON CHILONIDES.  19.

Chilon Chilonides at the service of the equal and the more equal. Petronius looks the man over with interest and then stare at Eunice. He regards her with amusement. Eunice blushes walks out in embarrassment.
Chilon smiles at Eunice as she runs out.
She complains of unrequited love. I gave her two threads from the mantle of Venus. I have my methods.
Are you a magician? The stranger pulls his clumsy hands from his worn coat. H smile contorts his face.
A philosopher, Master! Do you not know? Vinicius stands over Chilo.
Do You know what we want from you? Chilon squints his eyes.
I am to find some girl who has been abducted by her slave from a feast held by Caesar. Vinicius yells back in anger.

Only remember, this is not just some girl, you villain. It is the divine daughter of the King of the Lygians, called Callina! Chilon stares into PetroniusвЂ™s face, unsure who is in c and who holds the money. He is afraid of Vinicius. Petronius calms the situation.  20.
Do you have a way to do this?
If you have the means, sir, IвЂ™1l1 find a way.
So you are a philosopher for money, in other words a crook. Petronius seems cynical, as the newcomer once again fiddl with his old coat.

IвЂ™m saving up, to hire a scribe, whoвЂ™1l transmit my message to posterity. For myself, I do not keep a penny. Not even for a coat. From one side, Vinicius throws Chilon a bag jingling with coins. Even though he wasnвЂ™t looking, he catches it lik juggler.
When will you start? Chilon hides the bag in his jacket.
I already have! His tone becomes confident.
Noble lords, will you permit me to in turn ask a question or two? Petronius nods.
Did you notice the divine Lygia having any special marks: amulets, tattoos? Vinicius shakes his head. Chilon falls back and frowns.
It wonвЂ™t be easy. Vinicius comes to life and suddenly shouts.  21.
But wait! I remember now! She drew a fish in the sand! Chilo twists his head and mutters.
A Fish?
A Fish.
I shall do all in my power... but....you see for yourselves... you understand... Showing the holes in his coat as he slowly walks backward towards the exit and disappears. Petronius calls out to h
Tell my servant to give you a new coat! From outside the door Chilo calls back.

Thou art a true philosopher, Master! You hate even the slightest injustice. Eunice shows up in the doorway looking more beautiful tha usual. Petronius looks at her in amazement. Vinicius interrupts his staring.
What now? Petronius puts his fingers to his nose and, changing his voice, pretends to be Chilon.
First we fumigate the house, and then ask Eunice to accompany us. Eunice runs up to Petronius. He caresses the flowers in h hair and asks haughtily.
Could it be that love really exists? Happy is he who experiences it.  22.
Darkness. A gloomy path on which Chilon is sneaking benea gray walls. He runs into the first lit building, a winery
The interior of the winery. Chilon sits down at the neare table.
Wine, Sporus! The host puts a pitcher before him. The Greek pushes it away.

Something better than this, you swindler! The best in the house! He shouts out and throws a gold coin on the table. Sporus hands him a chalice. Chilon takes a huge gulp and pours t last bit onto the table top. He draws the shape of a fish in the wine. Sporus watches with a blunt expression.
Have you ever seen this sign? SporusвЂ™ face expressionless. A second gold coin falls o the table.
All types frequent this place.
Do you know who these are? Sporus mumbles.
Fish...people? A third gold coin falls on the table.
Can you at least count to three, fool? SporusвЂ™ eyes light up. He grabs the coins and wipes awa drawing in the wine.  23.
Fish in Greek is Ichthys. Jesus Christ, the Son of God, the Saviour.
Christ? The one who was crucified in Judea?
The same.

head_text.subj: SCENA 28A BEFORE SUNSET_INT_CRISPUS HOUSE VIEW TO THE ROO

text: A golden sunset, though the sky is still blue. Chilon sne up to the home of Crispus and cautiously looks inside. At a table are sat: the Apostles Peter and Paul, Crispus, Nazarius and Lygia. Peter breaks bread, dips a piece in w and passes it to Paul. He passes out the bread, doing the same for all those present. This scene is accompanied by music.
House of Petronius. In the doorway appears the haggard figure of Chilon.
Pax Vobiscum. Peace be with you. Vinicius grabs him, pulls him in and shakes him like a do
Where have you been, you villain!? He yells through clenched teeth. ChilonвЂ™s voice breaks as he wheezes.
DonвЂ™t choke me, Sir. IвЂ™m just a philosopher. Chilon wheezes and snorts trying to catch his breath.
Where is Lygia?  24.
SheвЂ™s safe, among her own people.
Meaning?
Your divine Lygia is a non-divine Christian. Vinicius is stopped in his tracks, but after a while, una to find an answer to this news, he turns to Chilon in a m friendly tone.
Do you now anything more?
More means more....for the both of us, less than tomorrow, but a lot more than yesterday. Chilon is alluding to extra payment.
HavenвЂ™t I paid you enough?
HavenвЂ™t I told you enough, Sir? Chilon immediately responds. Vinicius opens a box and pul out another purse with money for Chilon.
Here, take this, and youвЂ™1ll get a lot more when you lead me to her.

Darkness. Two hooded characters move through narrow alleyways. Behind them follows a hooded figure, the enorm and powerfully built Croto. The shortest of the three removes his hood, showing the face of Chilon.
Who is this, Sir? Chilon nods towards the second figure who takes his hood off.  25.
Croto. The Wrestler.
You are a cautious man, Sir. Guarding your virgin is a true giant. Vinicius shoves Chilon, whose hood falls over his face.
If you have lied to me, Croto will count your bones first and then he will deal with the giant!
But if IвЂ™m telling the truth?
You will receive a house and five slaves.

This very night, Christians will be gathering in Ostrianum. There is to be a man present who knew Christ. They call him "The Rock" - Petrus. The Apostle Peter. They are going to pray together. ThatвЂ™s where weвЂ™ll find her, Sir.

The three hooded figures are close to the entrance to a d ravine. Around them, ahead, on all sides and at the top o the ravine are hundreds of twinkling lights. The lights a concentrated in one meandering stream flowing down to the bottom of the ravine. Vinicius, Chilon and Croto, still hidden beneath their hoods, slow their pace, allowing others to hurry past the on their way up to the outlet of the ravine.

One of the caves in Ostrianum. Two fires burn by a wall t has windows giving a view over distant houses scattered along via Nomentana.  26. Lights go out in the houses as the residents go to sleep. Someone lights a bonfire with a torch, lighting up the ar then follows an interval filled with light and song. The shadows of those in attendance reflect off the side of th ravine. The cameraвЂ™s view is from behind Vinicius and Chilon. T men stand far back from the fires. By the fire stands the old Apostle Peter. He stands tall straight with dignity and inner strength. The light from fire illuminates his gray head and aged face. He speaks. Around him the hooded figures listen.
ThatвЂ™s the one, the first disciple of Christ, a fisherman! Peter raises his hand, making the sign of the cross, blessing the followers, who fall to their knees.

I have come to greet you in the name of He who sent me. I have come to tell you to renounce luxuries and pleasures. To love poverty, moral purity and truth. To endure patiently all harm and persecution, to beware of treachery, and set an example for one another. In ViniciusвЂ™s eyes we see the reflection of the fires. the influence of PeterвЂ™s words his face begins to chang the fire reflecting off of his eyes the gentle face of Ly appears.

I saw Him, and he was like light and the joy of our hearts, for we believed that He rose again and though the seas may dry up, and the mountains turn to dust, His glory shall not pass... Chilon tugs at ViniciusвЂ™s coat.
There! Take a look! HeвЂ™s right there! The giant! Vinicius turns his head in the direction of ChilonвЂ™s pointing finger. He sees the massive Ursus.  27.

At that moment, the followers begin to sing as they move forward to Peter and bow their heads. Peter dips a branch in water and baptizes them. Lygia stands next to Ursus, staring off in front of her a the dancing flames reflect off their faces, making her almost transparent. Vinicius takes off his hood.
Lygia! Vinicius rushes forward but Chilon holds him back, grabbi him by the coat.

Wait, Sire! YouвЂ™1ll bring disaster on our heads. When this is all over, weвЂ™ll follow them, and then, in the darkness, this fellow here... Chilon looks at Croto, who is standing behind them with h arms crossed over his chest. He makes a gesture with his hands as if breaking UrsusвЂ™s bones. He takes one step forward and directs his mindless, but faithful gaze on Vinicius.
Now?
High on the tops of the ravine we can see the silhouettes those returning home from the Christian meeting. The sky the background is slowly lightening as dawn approaches.
A dark alley. Chilon looks around the corner.
They went into that house. He whispers, nodding towards the gray facade of a house. Croto stands in front of the building opposite the entran  28.
Now? From behind him appears the shorter Vinicius.
Now! He cries out his decision and leads the way. Then they disappear into the hallway leading into the house, while Chilon hides behind the corner.
They walk down a long hallway. A large figure appears and blocks their progress. From the darkness emerges the face Ursus.
And who would you be seeking?
You! Croto screams and throws himself on the giant.
RAAAAAARUH! [Savage battle cry]
UNNH! [Grunts in reaction] The two giants fight.

Vinicius runs down the hallway and out into a courtyard. By a fireplace burning in the courtyard Lygia sits, accompanied by an old man, CRISPUS. Vinicius heads towards them. The fire illuminates the fac of Lygia and Crispus. Vinicius pushes the old man out of the way and grabs the girl. He runs back out of the courtyard. In his way lies fallen body of Croto. Ursus inflicts a heavy blow to ViniciusвЂ™s head. The fre Lygia calls out to the giant.  29.
No, Ursus!!! No! DonвЂ™t kill him! Vinicius slumps to the ground.
Darkness. Voices can be heard.
Kill me. His voice is full of sorrow.
He was lucky; you almost broke his neck, Ursus.
In my former life I killed a lot of people, but back then I did not know Christ.
Trust in the Lord, Ursus. He knows best why you were born with such strength. And such a great heart...

House of Crispus. Vinicius is lying on a bed with a serio head wound. He opens his eyes. Crispus leans over the injured Vinicius and wipes his forehead with a damp cloth. Ursus looks at him from a distance as Crispus treats him. In the corner, there is Nazarius sitting on a low stool. He is cutting a piece of wood to a form of a little bird. Lygia sits at the end of the bed. When Vinicius sees her he whispers with all his strength.
ItвЂ™s you, Lygia. Lygia looks at him with care.  30.
Peace be with you, Marcus. Crispus hands Vinicius a clean slate with a stylus.
God tells us to love our enemy, so we have dressed your wounds. Now write a note to your people, have them come for you. Vinicius tries to lift his head.

You want me to leave? Now, when IвЂ™ve found Lygia!? I have harmed her, itвЂ™s true. But I swear to the gods, to my gods, that I will not touch the woman I love more than my life. May your God also be my witness. Permit me to stay. If only for one day. ViniciusвЂ™ head falls back. Lygia, emotionally moved by his words, rises from the end the bed with her eyes turned to Crispus.
Let him stay. Let him live.

Dream of Vinicius and his POV. Water floods his vision. One can see how he is struggling with the waves. Around him is darkness, wind, a storm. He struggling, losing strength until he slides under the wat With his last ounce of strength, he pulls himself to the surface and reaches out to grab the end of an oar, by mea of which he is hauled into a boat. It turns out the perso who handed him the oar is Peter. The fishing boat is going across a wide fiery lake. A swe angelic hymn begins to play as the boat reaches a shore w clean golden sand. The white pigeon is silently gliding at the sky. End of P Vinicius wet and tired after battling the elements lies o his back in the boat.  31. Peter is not there anymore, as Lygia bends over Vinicius with a gentle, beautiful smile.
Come, follow me; IвЂ™11 show you the way!
Vinicius opens his eyes in the house of Crispus. His head rests on the lap of Lygia, who is stroking his forehead.
I saw your soul in a dream.
Lygia melts away like a ghost. It was a ghost, a dream. ViniciusвЂ™s head still rests motionless, but now itвЂ™s on a cushion instead of LygiaвЂ™s lap.
Lygia told me you should drink this, Master. Ursus comes closer to Vinicius and hands him a metal cup with some hot brew, the cup hidden in his massive hands.
Are you LygiaвЂ™s slave?
Where we come from, there are no slaves.
Where is that?
Where the forest has no end, where there are castles made of wood, and a great abundance of honey and bread. Where "yes" means "yes" and "no" means "no"  32.
And Lygia?

When you Romans appeared in our forests, LygiaвЂ™s father, our king died from a Roman arrow. Soon after that her mother died. Your leader Plautius took the child under his wing. Rome became her home. And Christ her consolation. There is a transition to a stable from this chamber. You see a donkey, which is eating hay in a shadow and suddenl a face of Lygia, hidden there, listening, close to the donkey - appears.
Christ! who is he, that he could bring consolation to the Romans!?
He who changes sorrow to joy. And death itself, which for you is the end of life, is for us the beginning. Lygia runs out of her hiding and faces Vinicius.
Yes! Believing in Christ we cannot be unhappy.
And I am happy believing in you. I donвЂ™t need Christ for that.
You are mistaken, Marcus. Christ is love.

If it is as you say, let me see for myself. Be my wife. We will celebrate the biggest wedding ever seen in Rome. I shall ask the emperor himself for his blessing... Lygia looks at Vinicius. Her eyes begin to fill with tears and she runs out of the room.  33.

Upset, Lygia runs out of the room and into the courtyard where fish are hung up and drying. Peter is sitting on a bench, leaning against his staff. N to him sits the taller and more powerfully built APOSTLE PAUL. NAZARIUS(16), PeterвЂ™s compagnion is sitting under the t HE stays silent, but his nimble finger turn a piece of wo and a knife. Now you can see a bird figurine that Nazariu sculpts. Running through the courtyard, she doesnвЂ™t notice them Paul speaks.
God bless you, my child. Lygia stops and turns around to look at them. Peter taps his staff on the flagstones beneath his feet. Lygia lowers her head and approaches them.
Sit down with us, young lady. Lygia sits down on the stones beside the bench and begins listen to their conversation.
Do you remember how you attended the wedding at Canaa in Galilee? Peter nods his head with a smile, remembering the old tim
But you werвЂ™nt there! How do you know about that?
You told me all about it yourself, remember?
My mind is weakened by old age, but John has written everything down. Have you read it?  34.
Yes, IвЂ™ve read the whole thing. You went to a wedding, and they ran out of wine.
And Jesus called a servant and said, "Fill the wine jars with water."

He blessed the love between the woman and the man. The apostles now look at Lygia sitting by their feet listening to the conversation. She begins to blush, but sits in silence with no need to speak, just to listen.

While the eyes of the one you love remain closed to the light of truth, avoid him so that he does not lead you into sin. But pray for him and know that thereвЂ™s no sin in your love. Paul glances at Peter.
Trust in your love. Christ has softened hearts even harder than the heart of one Roman. Peter nods his head.
Thrice I denied our Lord, but he forgave me and commanded me to be a good shepherd to the people. Apostle Paul stands up, turning out to be a large man.

House of Petronius. He lounges in a seat in his library. The soft light of the moon enters to the library. Eunice peeks around the corner, looks at Petrnonius as always, with love, as he quietly reads verses of Horace o loud.  35.

I will not all die, a greater part of me will rise again. As long as high priest climbes the Capitoline Hill... Petronius raises his eyes from the pages and continues to speak the verse in near silence. Petronius can see Eunice looking at him, unaware that she reflected in a huge mirror. He momentarily stops reciting and then suddenly ends the poem aloud, as if speaking to Eunice.
...May Melpomene, the muse of song take pride in what I have made of all talents she gave to me, and crown my head with laurel wreath. Without taking his eyes off Eunice, he puts down the book
Have you ever thought about freedom, Eunice? Eunice retreats behind her corner, hiding.
You could leave this place, if I were to free you. Eunice suddenly appears from around the corner again.
Oh no! Please donвЂ™t do any such thing, Master. Eunice approaches him from behind as he continues to look her in the large brass mirror.
Freed, you could go your own way, have a husband, children, a life of your own... Eunice falls to her knees.
You are my life, my Lord.  36.
But admit that you envy the beautiful Romans, their fine apparel, jewellery, hairstyles, lovers...

Love is not jealous or boastful, is not borne up by pride. Eunice looks into his eyes and then he sees what kind of innocent soul hides behind her beautiful face. He reaches out towards her with his hand but doesnвЂ™t touch her, as he were scared to touch such beauty. He motions to her to come closer.
But what if I sent you to work in the fields? What if I married another woman? Or had you whipped?
Love bears every kind of suffering, believes all things, sees hope everywhere, endures everything.
But sooner or later it ends, burns out and dies... Petronius slides out of his seat and reaches out towards Eunice without touching her, kneeling in front of her.
Love never dies.
Vinicius reclines by the pool in PetroniusвЂ™ home. He still has a bandage on his head. Petronius is sitting across the pool with Eunice on his l He says irritably.
And so you have gone quite mad. You free your slaves, distribute your fortune among the poor  37.
I have come to believe their teaching that happiness, beauty, and love are nothing but vanity.
If you want to repay evil with goodness ... then ... then what do you repay goodness with!? Vinicius raises his hand and interrupts Petronius. Petron begins to walk away.
I cannot repay their goodness with evil. Petronius angrily turns around.
Do you intend to accept the teachings of this ... Christ?!

When IвЂ™m ready.... I would like you to meet him too, Petronius. At that moment a beautiful Greek slave enters the room an hands Petronius a letter, he reads it and with a sigh thr the paper into the pool like a paper boat.
Caesar orders us to go together to Antium. I advise you not to refuse such a request.
I cannot leave Lygia.
If you do not wish to lose her for ever, better start packing before Redbeard notices your absence
I want nothing from Caesar. If IвЂ™m going anywhere, then I shall go with Lygia and the Plutiuses to Sicily. If that is what she wants... Petronius looks at Vinicius with growing pity.  38.
No one is free. Everyone has someone above him who decides whether he lives or dies. Keep that rule in mind. ChilonвЂ™s contorted face appears in the doorway.
Psst....
What is he doing here?! Chilon approaches them and reaching the pool, sits down, takes off his sandals, and dips his tired feet in the col water. He begins his game with a mysterious expression.
I know where to find.... Vinicius jumps to his feet.
You dare not speak her name! Chilon is completely surprised by this turn of events.

Why is that, sir? What has changed since you promised me a house and five slaves. Have I not kept my word? Vinicius grabs Chilon by his coat and lifts him up over t pool, his feet dangling above the water.
IвЂ™m telling you not to hang around here any more and to forget that you ever knew us.

If you drown old Chilo, youвЂ™1l be doing a favour to the enemies of Rome. Along with me will perish matters important to the Empire, saved in this head of mine. Chilon tries to tap his head. Vinicius eventually throws down at the edge of the pool.  39.

You are to cease your spying, now! And do not show up around! Vinicius throws a purse of coins towards the door. Chilon runs after it and catches it, already close to the exit. He turns around and looks at Vinicius with plots an revenge in his mind.
YouвЂ™re very generous, Sir. Chilo will never forget it. He gives a low bow an exits.

head_text.subj: SCENE 46-47 EVENING_ANTIUM AT THE SEA SIDE_EXT_TERRACE

text: Antium. A large terraced villa. Below can be seen the cal waters of the bay.

And so Troy burns, burns, burns... Nero, with a zither in his hands plays the last two chord pathetically picking at the strings as he leans against a rail under a blood red sunset. The groan of the zither endlessly prolongs the last notes NeroвЂ™s poem. He looks around at Petronius, Vinicius, Poppea and Tigellinus with an expression of boundless pride. Tigellinus claps his hands with an idiotic smile as he no his head, as if he was agreeing with what he had just hea

What do you say? Did you see the fire that consumes Troy? Tigellinus, you first - what do you think of my description. Nero is surrounded by Petronius, Vinicius, Poppea and Tigellinus. Servants move around silently in the backgrou Nero has just finished reading a poem, now he proudly coc his head and looks at those present. Tigellinus claps his hands in appreciation and nods.  40.
Amazing!
Amazing? Tigellinus! But was it true? Did you feel the fire burn your hands?! Tigellinus stutters like a pupil in front of the blackboa

Oh! Divine one! It burned and... blinded! Nero casts Petronius a contemptuous look. Moving across, he closely observes Poppea, who with a loo of indifference on her face, stuffs some grapes into her mouth. She has no understanding or interest in the poetry Caesar. With a look of disgust, Nero turns around and yells out t the servants with an impatient voice.

Clear the tables. Augusta is choking. Two servants instantly bring out trays and bowls. Meanwhile, Nero looks at Petronius intensely. Petronius withstands the long stare, and after a long pau pronounces his judgment.
Throw your verse in the fire, Caesar; that would be the best thing for it. Caesar tries to control his anger and squints at him.
What do you find so wrong in my description of the fire, Petronius, that you would have the fire consume it?
It is too cold.  41.
It burnt Tigellinus.
DonвЂ™t believe him, divine Caesar. Your talent could wipe Rome from the surface of the earth, let alone Troy! Hearing this, Nero calms down.
ItвЂ™s true. The gods gave me talent. That is why I am sharing it with you.

The greatest poet of Rome does not look for acclaim from his soldiers, but is worthy of eternal glory in the pantheon of fame. Nero swells with pride and looks at Tigellinus with contempt, who shrinks in his armor.
Tigellinus has the mind of a mouse and skin thin as a womanвЂ™s. Come back tomorrow, Petronius, and you will die in the flames. TigellinusвЂ™s face blackens with anger.
As a sculptor seeks his model, so I need to see a real fire.
At your command, Sire, I will order all of Antium to be set alight for you!
What is Antium for Caesar!

head_text.subj: SCENE 48 NIGHT_EXT_ANTIUM AT THE SEA SIDE_BEACH

text: Antium. Coast. Petronius and Vinicius walk slowly along a sandy beach. Jupiter shines like a lantern.  42.
ArenвЂ™t you playing with life and death? Wrapped in his thoughts, Petronius for a moment doesnвЂ™t reply.
If you want Caesar to agree to your wedding with Lygia, he must be pleased with himself.
So why do you tease Tigellinus?
Tigellinus does all he can to prejudice Caesar against me. Small waves lap the shore.
It is said he who lives by the sword, dies by the sword.
It is also said: if you want peace - prepare for war.
How are we to know what itвЂ™s all worth. IвЂ™m a soldier and you area diplomat ... who will judge us?
You yourself and I myself. The late evening horizon is illuminated by the sphere of Jupiter, lighting up the way for the two men walking acro the beach as tiny waves crash onto the shore.

head_text.subj: SCENE 49 EVENING_ANTIUM AT THE SEA SIDE_EXT_TERRACE

text: Small waves lap the sands. The crackling and popping of burning wood and houses. The great fire, born in NeroвЂ™s head, in his poem, reflects of the water. The flames were born in NeroвЂ™s head, in N poem. We can heard only the groan of his zithar.  43. Nero is watching from the terrace of a villa in Antium. H turns around and looks at the room of guests, as if waiti for applause. Petronius speaks first.
We need air, Caesar. We are suffocating and the fires of Troy will soon reach us.
What are you saying, Petronius? Have the stanzas of my poem made such an impression on you?
I am quite burning up and donвЂ™t know what will quench the fire. You have ruined my life, Sire. Vinicius, who remains stubbornly silent, could say the same, if he were not frozen with terror.
What have you to say about my fire - youвЂ™ve felt the fire of battle? Vinicius freezes, not knowing what to say in response to Nero. Tigellinus takes advantage.
Divine Caesar. Though I have been in a hundred battles... Nero, with a gesture signals him to be silent. He looks a Vinicius, expecting an answer. Petronius tries to help.
Vinicius would rather die than face the might of your poems, Nero. Nero breaks out into laughter.
Then you shall die, Vinicius, if you donвЂ™t tell me whether youвЂ™d prefer to receive a poem or a horse from me? Petronius is bitterly silenced.  44.

IвЂ™d rather have a poem, Sire.Horses there are many, but only one Caesar. Nothing is worth more than his words. NeroвЂ™s face lights up in appreciation and he cries out the servants from the terrace.
Bring me my horse! He turns to Petronius.

They think me a monster ... they call me matricidal, they are jealous of my talent. The burden of Magnitude is hard to bear. You alone understand me - the Artist! He puts his hand on PetroniusвЂ™s shoulder. Tigellinus as always looks on their relationship with jealousy. The servants bring along his horse beneath the terrace.

And I do so like to make people happy. Vinicius - the steed is yours! Confused, Vinicius looks at Petronius. Petronius nods reassuringly, implying that you canвЂ™t refuse Nero. Footsteps on the terrace approach from behind. Nero turns around. Faon, the freedman falls to his knees in front of Nero.
Forgive me, divine emperor! There is a fire in Rome! The greater part of the town on fire! Nero looks at him with curiosity then raises his eyes and hands.
Ye Gods! At last I shall see a burning city and finish my poem!  45.

The flames are swallowing up the people! Rome is dying, Sire! Vinicius walks off down the terrace, not listening to the conversation. He jumps on his horse and rides towards Rom Nero turns to Tigellinus.
Tigellinus. Will I be in time to see the fire? The face of Tigellinus shows great excitement as he savor NeroвЂ™s every word.
Sire, the show is for you.

A horse with its neck outstretched and panting heavily rushes past gardens and hedges. Vinicius leans over the horseвЂ™s neck. He urges the animal on. The horse and Vinicius reach the hill. On the horizon we the city engulfed in gold and pink, with flashes, like distant thunder.

The horse on top of the hill rears up on its hind legs. Vinicius calms him down and looks down on the city. The burning city can be seen in the distance, a mass of f and smoke. Vinicius heads down towards the city.

Vinicius tries to navigate with his horse through the chaotic crowds in the city. The forms of people are hard see through the thick black smoke. Every now and then a terrified face, black from the smoke flashes into view. Screams of pain, anger, and curses can be heard.
Death to Nero! Mother killer! Down with the tyrant! We know he did this! Assassins! Arsonists! Hang them all!  46.

Vinicius enters the street on which Crispus lives. From t entrance of the street fire can be seen. The fire quickly moves towards the rider, engulfing and consuming the vine surrounding him. The horse rears back in fear. A RUNAWAY runs past. Vinicius grabs him by his tunic, alm falling off of his horse.
Where are they!?

ThereвЂ™s no one here! The Christians have left for Ostrianum! He disappears in the smoke. The horse turns around. Its hooves pound on the flagstones of the street as it disappears into the clouds of smoke.

head_text.subj: SCENE 54 NIGHT_EXT_CRISPUS HOUSE_COURTYARD 2 DURING THE F

text: Vinicius on horseback enters a Courtyard. There are still tongues of fire on the walls and roof. Vinicius hangs limply over the horseвЂ™s neck. He falls, rolling onto the grass and lies on his back. His face is blackened with smoke. He falls unconscious.

NeroвЂ™s entourage stops at the edge of an aqueduct. Nero takes a few steps forwards and from the top looks down on the burning city. They are surrounded by scorched tree trunks and a growing angry crowd. Nero turns to his entourage and recites a short line with pathetic voice as he gestures towards the burning city.
Homeless ruler of a homeless people, where will I lay my miserable head this night... From beneath the aqueduct, the roaring of the crowd grows louder.  47.
Nero tunes his zither and looks down. Striking the string he begins to sing.

Oh star of my ancestors, dear birthplace ... Oh star of my ancestors, dear birthplace... After these few words, he throws the zither into a gap in the aqueduct where it smashes among the crowd below. Nero wraps himself in his robe and stands in statuesque pose. A sinister howl comes from the crowd down below.
WhereвЂ™s Caesar!?! He put us in hell! Death to Nero! Mother killer! Down with the tyrant! Nodding his head, Nero says plaintively
This is how the people appreciate me and my poetry. Tigellinus comes up beside him.
Have the praetorian guards called out to attack them, Sire. Petronius comes up on NeroвЂ™s other side.
Speak to your people, Sire and promise them something. Tigellinus glares at Petronius. Nero raises his head to t sky and with a heavy sigh sarcastically comments on the proposal.
Would you have the divine Caesar speak to the rabble? Nero stares at Tigellinus.
You go down to them! Tigellinus lowers his head in silence.  48.
Caesar, I will go.
Yes, you my most faithful ... Go and lavish promises on them!
Petronius alone stands on the edge of the aqueduct, stari at the crowd. He raises his arms and after a while the hubbub subsides.
Petronius! ItвЂ™s Petronius!
Citizens! From afar, Nero listens to Petronius, adding his own comments to the speech.
...And you scum...
The city will be rebuilt.
...as soon as weвЂ™re done with the show...
Caesars gardens will be opened to you.
...just donвЂ™t throw any garbage around or bring your goats...
From tomorrow, grain, wine and oil will be handed out!
...fill your bellies till you choke...
Then Caesar will organise for you games such as Rome has never seen before.  49.
and will never see again...
Great feasts and generous gifts await you!
...Rome has burnt to the ground - long live Rome!
Bread! Bread! Games! Bread and games!Bread! Bread! Games! Bread and games!

head_text.subj: SCENE 58 DAY_EXT_CRISPUS HOUSE_COURTYARD 2 BURNED AFTER T

text: Nazarius leans over Vinicius and splashes the riderвЂ™s f with water. Marcus Vinicius opens his heavy eyelids. The temporarily blinds him.
Our house is burned down, Master! Vinicius tries to pick himself up.
Where is she?!
An underground cavern. A few lights give a faint glow. Th cavern is filled with people kneeling and praying.
There are caves beyond the gardens of Agrippina. They have taken shelter there. Standing against a wall is a more clearly illuminated Pet the Apostle. He makes the sign of the cross with his hand
Peace be with you! The crowd responds with a murmur of pained and fearful voices.  50.
Do not abandon us! Do not leave us on this day of judgment! Peter raises his hands.

Woe to the world, and woe to the sinful. Fire has come to the city of crime, but the Lord has shown mercy to those of you washed by baptism! Peace be with you! Peter moves among the crowd, blessing them. Suddenly, he stands opposite Vinicius. Vinicius bows his head low. He looks around and sees a vat of water. Someon hands him a twig with a few leaves still swaying on it. Peter dips it into the water and sprays Vinicius with it, baptizing him.
I baptize you in the name of the Father, the Son and the Holy Spirit. Follow me.

Interior of a modest cottage on the outskirts of the city Lygia is busy hanging fish on a line. She does not see Vinicius who has entered and is standing, watching his beloved Lygia. When Lygia turns and sees Vinicius, she for a moment does not know what to do. But her feelings overcome her doubt she throws herself into his arms. There is a wooden pigeo sculptured by Nazarius sitting over their heads, on the ledge in the wall.
I promised you that IвЂ™d never leave you...
And then IвЂ™1l say "where you go Caius, there go I Caia".
This very day weвЂ™1l sail for Sicily. My house is your house.  51.

My heart is your heart. During this time Peter the Apostle has also entered the room. As he sees them in such a love and community, he approaches them and takes ViniciusвЂ™s right hand and joi with LygiaвЂ™s right hand.
Love one another. There is no sin in this love of yours. Vinicius looks into the eyes of Lygia.
I, Marcus Vinicius, take you Lygia Callina for my wife and promise that I will not leave you for as long as I live. Lygia looks into his eyes.
So help us, Lord God Almighty. Nazarius runs into the room.
The gladiators have revolted. They are killing everyone! Peter silences him with a gesture and directs his words t Vinicius.
This is a great evil In the distance we hear the growing roars of lions collec in an animal pit.

DonвЂ™t stray away, Father. IвЂ™1l come for you. Vinicius straitens Lygia for the last time and runs out o the room. The roars of the lions become increasingly loud and clear There are upcoming screams of people, as well.  52.
This way! Run! God! Help us! Horror overcomes the faces of those gathered.
Did He abandon His flock?
SCENE 61 DAY_INT_ROME_PALATINO_NEROвЂ™S CHAMBER
Palatino. NeroвЂ™s chamber.Petronius stares at Nero.
Sire, you need to go to Hellas. ItвЂ™s getting too dangerous in Rome. Tigellinus abruptly interrupts him.
That is not a good idea! Civil war could erupt before you get to Ostia, Sire! The Praetorians may betray us! Angry voices from a crowd approaches from a distance.
Death to the arsonists of Rome! Mother killer! Coward! Death to the tyrant! Arsonist! Burn him at the stake! Burn them all!
They have enough grain and oil, what more do they want?
Vengeance. Nero squints and collects his thoughts for a moment. Suddenly an idea comes to mind and he smiles evilly.
And vengeance requires a victim, Tigellinus. You must go out to them and admit it was you who set fire to Rome.  53. Tigellinus looks petrified. After a moment he looks at NeroвЂ™s with defiance.
I burned Rome on your orders! Nero and Tigellinus measure each other like wild beasts. The sudden voice of Faon standing in the doorway to the h interrupts the moment.

The divine Poppea wishes to see Tigellinus. SCENE 62 DAY_INT_ROME_PALATINO_POPPEAвЂ™S CHAMBER PoppeaвЂ™s Chamber. The Empress lies on a bed holding the collar of a huge leopard. In front of Tigellinus - Chilon
So, you say that Vinicius...?
Yes, Master.
And how about Petronius?
Perhaps! It may very well be. Poppea bursts into hysterical laughter.

DonвЂ™t be ridiculous, Tigellinus. Petronius, that lover of life and pleasure - a Christian? You wonвЂ™t protect us with this. The anger of the people will turn against Nero and will fall on me. Chilon falls to his knees and crawls towards Tigellinus, glancing at Poppea the entire time.
Vinicius is with them. I swear! Lygia too is a Christian. They have married. They mean to disappear from sight, and leave Nero in this stench of a burnt city.  54.
You came here with with? You have nothing on Petronius?! Chilon rubs his fingers together insinuating money. Tigellinus rejects him with a kick.

Catch the nephew in the net, and the uncle will fall into the trap of his own accord. And may I count on your good graces, Master? SCENE 63 DAY_INT_ROME_PALATINO_NEROвЂ™S CHAMBER The room in which Nero resides. Poppea and Tigellinus ent Nero laughs sheepishly, clearly nervous. From afar, under the Palatine, the screams of the crowd can be heard.
The mother killer set fire to Rome! Death to Nero!
ItвЂ™s getting nasty. We had better make our escape to Hellas. Caesar walks over to Tigellinus.
The people already know that it was Caesar who set fire to Rome!
If I so desire, I can turn the people against you.
I havenвЂ™t killed my mother. They remember Agrippina and havenвЂ™t forgiven you that... crime.
You played your part in it.
As in everything that goes on in the palace. Silence.  55. Petronius listens from the side of the room, looking out from a window at the hills covered by the figures of the growing crowd.

Do my ears deceive me, Nero; do you really intend to let this muscle-bound fool have the last word?! Tigellinus looks at Petronius as if he had been struck wi an arrow in the windpipe. All of a sudden he takes a more conciliatory tone.

The people need revenge and... someone to sacrifice. You have heard, Sire, of the followers of this prophet, Christ? As soon as we agreed to have him hung on the cross, they made a God of him.It was they who set fire to Rome! NeroвЂ™s face begins to assume an expression of anger, gr and indignation.
What did this poor city do to deserve such a crime ... at their hands? And what is Rome to do now, with these beasts? Poppea walks up to the emperor.
They are your enemies! Punish the arsonists!
They go around the city trying to convince people to turn against Caesar. Nero makes another theatrical gesture.

What punishment and torment fits such a crime? Petronius comes out of the shadows, silently and intently watching the faces of Poppea and Tigellinus and then Nero He starts to talk with a growing power in his voice.  56.
Beware, Sire, for they will say that Nero burned Rome, but threw the blame on the innocent. Nero - the coward. Tigellinus stands by Nero.
One word from you, and Petronius will forever hold his peace. Nero looks at Petronius, cocking his head, feeling hurt. Petronius
Though he has wounded my heart, I still love him like a brother.
If you treat your brother as you treated your mother, there will soon be nobody in the world to love you. walks out silently.
House of Petronius. PORTERS quickly bring a litter throug the gate. Eunice is Petronius Petronius gets out and heads towards the entrance. there to greet him.
Vinicius was waiting for you! He wanted to say goodbye. This very day, he departs with Lygia for Sicily. embraces her affectionately.
And if it should happen that we had to part?
Where you go, Master, there I go.
Some voyages have to be taken alone.  57.

Take me with you. Petronius strokes her golden hair and with his arm around her they both enter the house. From inside can be heard their voices, interrupted by EuniceвЂ™s laughter, as if they were children playing.
I have no right to decide about the life of the beautiful Eunice.
Eunice belongs to you.
Then I am the happiest man in Rome. There are some things that cannot be taken from me.

head_text.subj: SCENE 65 PETRONIUS PALACE HALL VIEW THROUGH THE WINDOW

text: He has barely crossed the threshold of his house, when Petronius must regretfully put an end to EuniceвЂ™s joy.
Forgive me. I do not ask you to accompany me. His face maintains a carefree expression, trying to hide depression. He kisses Eunice on the forehead, turns aroun and disappears into his library.

Library. Petronius is writing, leaning over his desk. We his outline from behind, along with the outline of column leading to the garden. After a few moments, Paul the Apostle appears in the entrance. He stands for a moment looking at Petronius.

You do not want her to accompany you and you are setting her free. Note well GodвЂ™s goodness and severity: he was severe with cut branches, and for you he is good - if you persist in this goodness. At the sound of his voice, Petronius looks up, confused.  58.
Who are you? A thief?
They told me I would find Vinicius here. I say to you, I, Paul, a servant of Christ Jesus, called to be an apostle to preach the good news from God. Petronius snorts and laughs bitterly.
"Enemy of Rome!" "Arsonist"! Are you here seeking revenge?

Do not mete out justice yourselves, but leave that to God. "I mete out punishment, and I will repay for everything" - says the Lord. DonвЂ™t be overcome by evil, but overcome evil with good. Stunned by the discussion, Petronius stands up and paces room.
Good? What is that compared to wealth, fame and happiness, which the tyrant can destroy at a momentвЂ™s notice?
Wish well for those who persecute you. Live in harmony with one another. Do not pretend to love, but really love other people.
Death cancels everything. Have you not heard the groans of victims?
If we believe that Jesus died and rose again, God will take those who have died in Jesus and lead them into eternity.
If God is on your side, what will become of those who are against you?  59. Petronius lifts his head to hear the reply, but Paul is n longer there.
Street of Rome. Crowd. You can hear the roar and drunken singing of the crowd among the ruins of the still smoking city.

Christians to the lions! They poison our wells! Let the animals at them! Get rid of these fanatics! Death to all Christians! Death to all Christians! The litter with Vinicius is having trouble moving through the crowd. After a while it disappears into the smoke.

Petronius stands with his back to the library table, exac where Paul stood before. Standing in the dark corner, he looks out the window at the vegetation growing around the columns of the atrium. He doesnвЂ™t turn round at the sound of Vinicius approach
Caesar has accused the Christians of setting fire to Rome! Vinicius, angry, runs into the library.
Have you hidden her?
They sent over a hundred Praetorians after them. They took everyone away. The elderly, women and children. Did you know about this?
LetвЂ™s say that I underestimated Tigellinus. What about Lygia?
Apparently sheвЂ™s together with the others in prison.  60. Petronius claps his hands. Out of nowhere his female servants appear.
Bring swords and mantles. Finally Petronius turns around, but his face is still hid in the shadows.
YouвЂ™1l1 have to bribe the guards to release her immediately. Otherwise it will be too late!
Talk to Caesar. Nero loves you. He will release her for you.
Do you think a man who sentenced his own mother to death can love? Today, IвЂ™m the first he would deprive of a voice and the last person heвЂ™d like to hear.
Dressed in mantles, Petronius and Vinicius approach the prison walls. As they get closer they see a double line o soldiers surrounding the sealed entrance to the prison.

Arsonits! They burned down Rome! Death to Christians! Let the animals at them! Get rid of these fanatics! Death to Christians! Throw them to the lions! LetвЂ™s rid the city of these fanatics! Death to all Christians! LetвЂ™s see their God save them now! Petronius searches for the commander, eventually spots hi and approaches him. It is KRICSOS.
Hail, Kricsos! You have been ordered to guard the jail? Kricsos stands at attention.  61.
Yes, noble Petronius. The Prefect fears there may be an attempt to free the arsonists.
My slave is in there. This is some mistake. I know her well and I know that she had nothing to do with them.
My orders are to let no one out! Despite this, Petronius takes a step forward, Niger block his path.
DonвЂ™t you dare.... You can hear the clinking of weapons from the PRAETORIAN GUARDS.
That means no one, Sir.
And are you also forbidden to let anyone in?
....That was not prohibited.

So tell your men to let me through the cordon. I want to find those who burned down my house. After a few moments of debating this in his head, Kricsos gives his men the signal to let them in. Vinicius turns round, embraces Petronius, says goodbye an enters the prison.

Vinicius passes over the threshold of the prison and is enveloped in darkness. The hallways and cells are filled with people. They stand calmly, quietly, most of them are praying. Words of prayer reverberate throughout the priso  62.

Our Father who art in heaven, hallowed be thy name. Thy kingdom come.Thy will be doneon earth as it is in heaven.Give us this day our daily bread, and forgive us our trespasses,as we forgive those who trespass against us,and lead us not into temptation,but deliver us from evil. In the meantime, Vinicius wanders around helplessly, look for Lygia. A CENTURION approaches Vinicius; he leans over and whispers in his hear.
IвЂ™ve seen you before, Sir. In Ostrianum.
Are you....? With his long Gallic sword the centurion draws a fish in sand.
I must find Lygia.
SheвЂ™s no longer here. Vinicius grabs him by the shoulder.
Do you know where she is now? The centurion shakes his head.
Well, do you know how to get out of here? Centurion turns around, nods his head towards Vinicius an disappears into the darkness.

Vinicius exits through a side door from the darkness of t prison and comes out into afternoon sunlight.  63. He takes a few steps and encounters the Apostle Paul. He sees him, however, from a distance across the entire widt of the street. The Apostle looks in ViniciusвЂ™s face. A litter passes between Paul and Vinicius. The voices of its PORTERS can be heard.
Make way for the noble Chilo! Make way! Vinicius grabs the edge of the litter and tips it in his direction. Chilon slides across to him, his eyes wide wit surprise.
Greetings to you, Chilo. Chilon tries to cover his face with his arm.
Hail, Vinicius, but do not hold me up. I hasten to my friend Tigellinus! Vinicius grabs him by the robe and screams.
It was you who betrayed them! Chilon replies arrogantly.

My friend, if you have a request, come to my house. I welcome all visitors and clients in the morning, after I have taken my bath. Vinicius is still half holding on to his tunic. SLOW MOTION. Some invisible force pulls Vinicius back. He looks back and meets the eyes of Paul. In one flash of tr there is an explosion of energy and agreement between the two men. Vinicius turns his head back on Chilon and looks deeply i his eyes.
May God forgive you. Vinicius then finally lets go of his tunic and lets the litter pass on.  64. Vinicius then looks back to where Paul was standing, but is already gone.

Appian Road is empty at this time of a day. There is only long shadow of PETER THE APOSTLE, who looks ahead at the hilly surrounding area. Beneath his hood you can see his grave expression and tired face. The sun begins to appear from over the hillsides. Peter shields his eyes with his hand, trying to see the white pigeon, which flapped its wings loudly. Peter sinks to his knees, resting his hands and head on h staff. Around his outline appears a pulsing, golden light Than the single beam of light splits like a prism into tw streaks - one of them is pale pink - another clear luminous. The staff slides from under him and he falls face down in the Sand, his head still covered by his hood. Peter stretches his hands forward as if reaching for someoneвЂ™ feet. Silence falls. The golden light fades. Peter raises his h slightly.
Quo Vadis, Domine?
If you abandon my people, I shall go to Rome to be crucified once again.

Christ! Forgive me! Suddenly, there is Nazarius coming from the distance. He pulls the bridle of a gray Donkey. The Donkey denies to g with four hooves. Each step is difficult for them. Nazarius managed to pull up the Donkey. The confused face of Nazarius as he bends down over the o man. Then from above them a pained voice speaks out. The golden light fades as Nazarius grabs Peter and helps up off his knees.  65.

Let us not delay, Peter, at any time they may catch up with us here. The Apostle Peter gets up, and leaning on his cane turns around to stare in the direction of Rome. Suddenly he hea back towards the city. Nazarius catches up to him and gra his arm, trying to stop him.
Where are you going, Master? Peter slowly turns his head, holding his staff in one han and pointing towards the city with the other.
To Rome! In the distance you can see the Circus.

The Arena of the big Circus. View from the imperial terra towards the audience. Nero sits on an elevated podium with the magnificently dressed Poppea beside him. They are surrounded by the cou Petronius is sitting next to Tigellinus. Chilon is on the right hand side. The place to the left of Petronius is empty. Petronius looks around. Vinicius takes a seat next to his uncle.
Have you found her? Vinicius shakes his head. Nero looks towards Petronius and Vinicius. He gets up. The crowd in the Circus roars and cheers.
Nero! Nero! Divine Augustus! Christians to the lions!  66.

Arena. Massive gates are located on the left and right si of the arena. The shrill sound of trumpets breaks the silence. As soon as the trumpets fall silent, the gate on the righ side opens with a crash. From the black depths of the ope gate emerge human figures that slowly move towards the center of the arena. The crowd in the Circus murmurs.
Christians! Christians! Christians! The Christians huddle together in the middle of the arena squinting under the sun. They kneel and bow their heads together while holding each other.

Bring on the animals! The animals! The trumpets begin to play again. The gate on the left si of the Circus opens. From a black tunnel emerges a lion. Behind it, more lions rush out. The animals sniff the air, growl and squint in the bright light. The crowd Howls with delight. From the middle of the cluster of Christians comes the so -"Christus Regnat".

The scene is accompanied by music. Images shown from a distance, without dramatic shots. NeroвЂ™s terrace. With his sapphire monocle, Caesar looks on the arena. PoppeaвЂ™s eyes shine with excitement. She embraces her husbandвЂ™s neck and shoulders. Tigellinus wears an expression of contempt and triumph. A lion lurks closer, readying to pounce on the tight clus of kneeling people. He pounces and seizes in its mouth th neck of an old man. The crowd goes wild. Increasingly horrified by this sight, Chilon slides lower and lower into his seat. The lions drag their victims across the sand, the arena i now filled with the screams of those being murdered.  67.
ChilonвЂ™s head is tilted back unnaturally. Face pale, ey closed, sweaty forehead. With a wild roar of laughter Tigellinus jerks ChilonвЂ™s arm.
Look! Look! This is your doing! Petronius from behind Tigellinus reaches out towards Chil With his carved cane he taps lightly on his pulsating Ada apple.
The gods created him a foul villain. He has become a veritable demon! But even a demon cannot endure this. Chilon wheezes, his eyes shut tight. He reaches breaking point.

Enough, Caesar! Enough! Vinicius looks up. He sees something and nudges Petronius arm. Petronius follows his gaze. At the top of the arena stands Peter, making the sign of the cross with his hand. Standing in the light, he looks like a ghost.
Look! Peter is here! PeterвЂ™s piercing eyes are looking straight at Petronius Instead of Peter, all he can see is s pigeon in an oncomi white pigeon.

I canвЂ™t see anyone. PeterвЂ™s piercing eyes are looking straight at Petronius even though he denies his existence. Suddenly, a big whit pigeon is appearing, where Peter was supposed to stand. Some strange energy passes between them. The howling of t crowd in the Circus mixes with the roars of the maddened animals. Tigellinus leans into NeroвЂ™s ear.
I have something even better arranged for tomorrow.  68.

Twilight. Palatine Gardens. The area where cypress trees once grew is now covered with large crosses. On these are tied half naked people, their arms attached to the crosse by thick ropes, their heads hanging down, their bodies covered in bruises and marks from beatings. The crosses are draped in dry garlands of ivy. Suddenly a large peal of trumpets. Nero looks down on the scene from the windows of the Palatine. He makes a gesture and puts his monocle to his to examine the nearest cross. On it hangs Crispus. Standing next to Nero is the pale Chilon, swaying on his feet.

Darkness falls. Close-up of the crucified Crispus. His he slowly rises. The victim is still alive. He opens his eyes and stares a Chilon. His chapped lips move silently, his chest rising with each breath as his face shines. He whispers.
I forgive and ask for forgiveness.

Set the fire. The ivy is immediately lit, lighting up the main avenue o the garden as the flames travel up the shafts of the crosses. ChilonвЂ™s white robe shines yellow and purple in the reflection of the fires. He hides his face in his hands a is shaken by spasms.

Chilon runs down the middle of the avenue past the burnin crosses, the flames whipping at him as he tries to find a exit from the garden. Once past the fires, he trips and falls, crashing to the ground.  69.
A hooded figure bends over Chilon and touches his arm. Chilon fears to open his eyes.
I am cursed, damned. The face of Paul emerges from under the hood.
I bring you salvation.
For me there can be no salvation. Paul then draws a cross on his forehead. From ChilonвЂ™s comes a moan.
Christ! The Apostle Paul disappears back into the darkness.
Trumpets, noise and fanfare. Suddenly out of the darkness emerges a figure wearing a s covered robe. He stands in front of the imperial retinue. is Chilon. He points at Nero.
Murderer of your own mother! Woe to you! It was you who set fire to Rome. And Rome will have its vengeance on you. Your time has passed. He points dramatically at the burning crosses.

I swear that the innocent are being killed here. The arsonist of Rome is this one! This man! With his right hand Chilon points at Nero and freezes in that pose. Silence falls. At first single voices are hear then a growing number of ominous cries rise up from the crowd.  70.
Arsonist! Murderer! Tyrant! Mother Killer! Despot! Redbeard! Down with Caesar! Down with tyranny!

A still burning stake collapses in front of the caravan o horses, scaring them and knocking Chilon to the ground. H head and neck are showered with sparks and burning splinters. The frightened horses panic and stampede, trampling Chilon. Wheels run over his limp body.
SCENE 84-85 DAY_INT_ROME_PALATINO_NEROвЂ™S CHAMBER

Arsonist! Murderer! Tyrant! Mother Killer! Nero the murderous dog! Who set our city on fire?! You burnt my house, you dog! We will have vengeance! Chamber in Pallatino - the palace of the emperor. Nero is walking around the chamber.
The ship is waiting in Naples, Caesar.
So we shall take a vacation on Hellas after all? Petronius stands before Caesar.
Before you sail Sire, and deprive us of your divine presence, do faithful Petronius one last favour.
WhatвЂ™s that supposed to mean?
Bless the young couple.  71.
YouвЂ™re getting married?
Vinicius wants to marry the Lygian hostage.
Nero, sheвЂ™s one of them. SheвЂ™s in the prison.
She found herself there through your stupidity, Tigellinus. TigellinusвЂ™s face turns black with anger. Nero squints suspiciously.
One thing that worries me, Petronius, is that you take sides with the arsonists. Now Nero looks at Tigellinus.
We will organise a wedding the likes of which Rome has never seen.

Twilight. In front of PetroniusвЂ™s home. The sky is cove in driving clouds. Fires lit in the house cast long shado along the walls. Leaning against the columns of the house is Vinicius, waiting for word from Petronius. At the sight of his chariot, he jumps up and waits at the front for it to sto

Tell me that you bring her freedom! Petronius does not reply right away. Then from the darkne appears a figure in a gray tunic. HeвЂ™s obviously in hid He looks around nervously, making sure he isnвЂ™t being followed. He whispers.
Is that you, noble Vinicius?  72.
Nazarius? Where did you come from?
I have a message from Lygia. In her fever she keeps repeating your name. Ursus is with her.
How do you know this?
I know a centurion.
IвЂ™m going with you! Nazarius begins to run off in panic. He stops, turns, and from a distance conveys the most important part of his message.

Lygia asks you, Master, to persevere in your love and trust of God. Nazarius raises his eyes towards heaven. The moonlight filters directly onto his face. Suddenly the heavens open with lightning and thunder. The sudden downpour soaks the Nazarius disappears in the pouring rain and darkness. Vinicius cries out to him, but the rain drowns out his words.
I will wait for her! Always! Petronius wraps his arm around Vinicius and forcefully brings him inside.
Pull yourself together, soldier. Or pray, if you know how.

Circus. Brilliant sunlight. Nero is on the terrace. With is Tigellinus, Poppea, and even Hasto, Pitagoras and Faon The sand in the arena has turned to pools of mud from the rain.  73. Petronius sits away from Nero, in an adjacent terrace, ne to Vinicius, who is as white as a sheet. With dark rings under his eyes, he stares at the gates. Behind them armed PRAETORIANS hold prisoners. AS always, a peal of trumpets marks the beginning of the spectacle. Nero is curious how the spectacle is affecting Petronius and his nephew. He canвЂ™t resist staring at th through his monocle. Suddenly he bursts out laughing and shouts to Tigellinus, who is leaning on NeroвЂ™s chair.
I underestimated you, Tigellinus. YouвЂ™re worse than me.
I had lessons from the best master Nero.

I can do anything, but youвЂ™ve managed to amaze Petronius himself. Look! Petronius looks pale and exhausted. He slowly stands up. he can be seen standing tall above the others, staring at one point in the arena. He slowly turns his head and look straight at Nero. Very slowly and clearly he speaks over noise of the trumpets.

If their God really exists, what will become of those who are against Him? The gate on the right opens, revealing the dark abyss of tunnel. A moment later a huge athletic figure emerges.
